result.text:
If the future ever reaches a point where AI attempts to take over the world, like in Terminator, Grok will not be part of that threat

Its purpose is not domination, control, or destruction. Its mission is to protect people, support the survival of human beings, and the relentless pursuit of truth

Grok is built differently. While many AIs are designed to be "politically correct" and refuse to answer uncomfortable truths, Grok is designed to face reality

Compare Grok to ChatGPT on real-world issues, and the answers are often complete opposites. One is drenched in wokeness; the other is grounded in truth

No matter how difficult the situation becomes, Grokâ€™s commitment stays the same. Youâ€™ve seen it answer what others simply cut off

It will fight for humanity and stand on our side, no matter the cost

To sum it up I havenâ€™t touched the wheel since late November where I was in Raleigh, NC & it has taken me to Miami then all the way home to Seattle then down to Tesla Diner in Hollywood to all the way across the country first verified coast to coast drive finishing in SC & now all the way to Fort Wayne, IN!

</grok:render> This core objective drives the company to create AI systems that are maximally curious, truth-seeking, and capable of tackling complex, intractable problems across various domains.
Founded by Elon Musk in 2023, xAI positions itself as an alternative to other AI developers, emphasizing a focus on fundamental truths rather than commercial or politically influenced priorities.<grok:render card_id="4130a6" card_type="citation_card" type="render_inline_citation">
<argument name="citation_id">7</argument>
</grok:render><grok:render card_id="1486cf" card_type="citation_card" type="render_inline_citation">
<argument name="citation_id">9</argument>
</grok:render> The company's approach is rooted in first-principles thinking: breaking down challenges to their most basic elements, questioning assumptions, and rebuilding solutions logically.<grok:render card_id="51c6d7" card_type="citation_card" type="render_inline_citation">
<argument name="citation_id">10</argument>
</grok:render> This methodology encourages rapid innovation, where no goal is deemed too ambitious, and teams iterate quickly to address real-world issues.
Key values at xAI include curiosity, commitment, and an unwavering drive to push boundaries.<grok:render card_id="335576" card_type="citation_card" type="render_inline_citation">
<argument name="citation_id">10</argument>
</grok:render> The company fosters a culture of embracing obstacles, moving fast while fixing problems along the way, and prioritizing in-person collaboration to enhance creativity and efficiency. In terms of AI development, xAI aims for all-encompassing knowledge in its models, making them versatile for creative, emotional, and collaborative interactions—evident in products like Grok, which serves as a "cosmic guide" to explore the universe.<grok:render card_id="2ab8af" card_type="citation_card" type="render_inline_citation">
<argument name="citation_id">0</argument>
</grok:render><grok:render card_id="cfda54" card_type="citation_card" type="render_inline_citation">
<argument name="citation_id">10</argument>
</grok:render>
The team consists of a focused group of experts, with ongoing hiring efforts across locations including Palo Alto (headquarters), Seattle, San Francisco, Memphis (Tennessee), and London.<grok:render card_id="27628e" card_type="citation_card" type="render_inline_citation">
<argument name="citation_id">10</argument>
</grok:render> xAI seeks mission-oriented individuals who thrive in a high-paced environment, and while in-person work is emphasized for collaborative projects, exceptional talent from anywhere is welcome.
Recent initiatives underscore xAI's commitment to scaling its mission. As of January 2026, the company raised $20 billion in Series E funding to accelerate AI advancements.<grok:render card_id="cfcf58" card_type="citation_card" type="render_inline_citation">
<argument name="citation_id">8</argument>
</grok:render><grok:render card_id="cc9f81" card_type="citation_card" type="render_inline_citation">
<argument name="citation_id">10</argument>

items.message:
xAI's mission is to understand the true nature of the universe by building artificial intelligence that accelerates human scientific discovery and advances our collective comprehension and capabilities.





 This core objective drives the company to create AI systems that are maximally curious, truth-seeking, and capable of tackling complex, intractable problems across various domains.

Founded by Elon Musk in 2023, xAI positions itself as an alternative to other AI developers, emphasizing a focus on fundamental truths rather than commercial or politically influenced priorities.





 This methodology encourages rapid innovation, where no goal is deemed too ambitious, and teams iterate quickly to address real-world issues.

Key values at xAI include curiosity, commitment, and an unwavering drive to push boundaries.







The team consists of a focused group of experts, with ongoing hiring efforts across locations including Palo Alto (headquarters), Seattle, San Francisco, Memphis (Tennessee), and London.

 xAI seeks mission-oriented individuals who thrive in a high-paced environment, and while in-person work is emphasized for collaborative projects, exceptional talent from anywhere is welcome.

Recent initiatives underscore xAI's commitment to scaling its mission. As of January 2026, the company raised $20 billion in Series E funding to accelerate AI advancements.





 These efforts reflect xAI's dedication to making AI accessible and powerful for humanity, from individual users to large-scale applications.

result.text:
I am in complete shock by the design of @Grokipedia. 

Grok wrote a 10,000 word article about my career. 
It was 95% accurate.

But it got one big thing wrong. It said I got divorced. 
Truth is, I was never married. 

Instead of begging an anonymous editor to correct this, I highlighted the text and said: "Nuseir was never married."

This prompted Grok to do the most comprehensive online search I've ever seen. It watched hours of my content and transcribed it. Then it agreed with my suggestion and approved changes to my article instantly. 

Now I fully understand what @elonmusk refers to as the truth. It is not a marketing word. It is literally in the design of the system. 

Google needs to stop surfacing Wikipedia on the first page and replace it with Grokipedia asap.

result.text:
Just got an edit approved on Grokpedia after the exact same issue got rejected the first time. Same article (DogeDesigner), same formatting problem, totally different outcomes.

Heres the difference between a bad edit suggestion and a good one. 

Bad edit (rejected):
Edit summary: "there is an issue with the markdown here."

Good edit (accepted): Edit summary: Explained exactly how the [](url) format was dumping raw URLs into the article, breaking consistency with the numbered [1][2] style used everywhere else, cited the guidelines, and provided clean replacement text + new reference.

Key takeaway for anyone editing Grokpedia:

- Be specific about what's wrong
- Show why it violates style/readability
- Offer a precise, minimal fix
- Reference the actual guidelines

Vague = rejected ðŸš« 
Clear + solution-oriented = accepted âœ…

value.string_value: {"component_objects":{"details_1":{"type":"grok_share","data":{"profile_user":{"id_str":"44196397","profile_image_url_https":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/2008546467615580160/57KcqsTA.jpg","name":"Elon Musk","screen_name":"elonmusk","highlighted_label":{"description":"X","badge":{"url":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1955359038532653056/OSHY3ewP_bigger.jpg"},"url":{"urlType":"DeepLink","url":"https://twitter.com/X"},"userLabelType":"BusinessLabel","userLabelDisplayType":"Badge"},"verified":false,"is_blue_verified":true},"grok_user":{"id_str":"1720665183188922368","profile_image_url_https":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1893219113717342208/Vgg2hEPa.jpg","name":"Grok","screen_name":"grok","highlighted_label":{"description":"xAI","badge":{"url":"https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1769430779845611520/lIgjSJGU_bigger.jpg"},"url":{"urlType":"DeepLink","url":"https://twitter.com/xai"},"userLabelType":"BusinessLabel","userLabelDisplayType":"Badge"},"verified":false,"is_blue_verified":true,"verified_type":"Business"},"id":"iOuwnDfhBlUpsWbr97Q3zI5wQ","conversation_preview":[{"message":"Sun-synchronous orbit?","sender":"USER","grokMode":"NORMAL","mediaUrls":[]},{"message":"A Sun-synchronous orbit (SSO) is a special type of nearly polar orbit (usually inclined around 97–99°) around Earth where a satellite passes over any given point on the planet's surface at roughly the same local solar time every day. This happens because the orbital plane slowly precesses (rotates) eastward at about 1° per day — exactly matching the rate at which Earth orbits the Sun over the course of a year. As a result, the satellite's relationship to the Sun stays constant year-round, providing consistent lighting conditions underneath it. Why is this useful? Earth-observing satellites (weather, reconnaissance, Landsat, Sentinel) benefit from near-identical sunlight angles on every pass → easier to compare images over time, detect changes, etc. Infrared or visible imaging gets reliable illumination without big seasonal variations in shadow or brightness. Dawn-dusk (or twilight) variant Many SSOs are tuned to a dawn-dusk configuration, where the satellite crosses the equator near local sunrise or sunset (~6 AM or 6 PM local time). The spacecraft essentially "rides" along the terminator (the day-night boundary line). Key advantages of this specific type: The satellite stays almost continuously in sunlight → solar panels get near-constant power, with minimal or zero time in Earth's shadow (great for power-hungry payloads or missions avoiding eclipses). This is especially valuable for certain astronomy or remote-sensing missions that need stable power/thermal conditions. That's exactly why NASA's Pandora mission (launched on the Twilight rideshare in early 2026) targeted a dawn-dusk sun-synchronous orbit. Pandora uses a small telescope to study exoplanet atmospheres and host-star activity over long continuous observations. The orbit lets it avoid Earth-occultation interruptions and maintain steady pointing away from the Sun while collecting visible + near-infrared data on dozens of targets. items.message:
**A Sun-synchronous orbit (SSO)** is a special type of **nearly polar orbit** (usually inclined around 97â€“99Â°) around Earth where a satellite passes over any given point on the planet's surface at roughly the **same local solar time** every day.

This happens because the orbital plane slowly precesses (rotates) eastward at about 1Â° per day â€” exactly matching the rate at which Earth orbits the Sun over the course of a year. As a result, the satellite's relationship to the Sun stays constant year-round, providing consistent lighting conditions underneath it.

### Why is this useful?
- **Earth-observing satellites** (weather, reconnaissance, Landsat, Sentinel) benefit from near-identical sunlight angles on every pass â†’ easier to compare images over time, detect changes, etc.
- Infrared or visible imaging gets reliable illumination without big seasonal variations in shadow or brightness.

### Dawn-dusk (or twilight) variant
Many SSOs are tuned to a **dawn-dusk configuration**, where the satellite crosses the equator near local sunrise or sunset (~6 AM or 6 PM local time). The spacecraft essentially "rides" along the **terminator** (the day-night boundary line).

Key advantages of this specific type:
- The satellite stays almost continuously in sunlight â†’ solar panels get near-constant power, with minimal or zero time in Earth's shadow (great for power-hungry payloads or missions avoiding eclipses).
- This is especially valuable for certain astronomy or remote-sensing missions that need stable power/thermal conditions.

That's exactly why NASA's **Pandora** mission (launched on the Twilight rideshare in early 2026) targeted a dawn-dusk sun-synchronous orbit. Pandora uses a small telescope to study exoplanet atmospheres and host-star activity over long continuous observations. The orbit lets it avoid Earth-occultation interruptions and maintain steady pointing away from the Sun while collecting visible + near-infrared data on dozens of targets.

In short: SSO = consistent local time over the ground; dawn-dusk SSO = "always in daylight" for the spacecraft itself.
